Unlike the international criminal tribunals for Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia, the special court for Sierra Leone was set up in the same country where atrocities were committed.
Nonetheless, this week the court requested that the Charles Taylor war crimes trial be moved to the International Criminal Court Building in the Hague.
I asked the chief prosecutor, Desmond de Silva, who would have jurisdiction if the trial is moved?
When the court sits in The Hague, if it sits in The Hague, it will be the special court for Sierra Leone sitting in The Hague.
It'll have nothing to do with the international criminal court.
Now, there's been some criticism of another international criminal tribunal, the one for Rwanda, located in neighboring Tanzania.
And the complaint is that it's largely divorced from the lives of those who were wronged.
And I'm wondering if part of delivering justice is the catharsis for the wronged population, isn't some of that lost if you move the trial?
Not so with this tribunal because, after all, there are nine indictees charged with major war crimes and crimes against humanity.
On trial at the moment, in Sierra Leone, hundreds of witnesses have given evidence.
The population of Sierra Leone has watched justice being delivered on their doorstep.
In this one instance, neighboring Liberia has called for Charles Taylor to be tried outside the region.
He's being moved to avoid a further catastrophe in this region, a catastrophe which the people of Sierra Leone have already been the victim.
Last month, this special court in Sierra Leone amended the number of charges against Mr. Taylor, cutting the number from 17 to 11.
What was the reason for that?
Well, I wanted to provide for a more compact and swifter trial.
None of the gravity of the original allegations has been lost.
Charles Taylor now stands indicted for war crimes, crimes against humanity, other serious violations of international humanitarian law, including sexual slavery and mutilations.
The indictment has been slimmed down so as to provide for a swifter trial with fewer witnesses, which one should try and do in cases of this kind.
There is a complaint in the international community that all these trials take a hugely long time.
You look at the Milosevic case, for example.
He died before the end.
And so it is important that justice is also delivered relatively quickly.
Desmond de Silva is the chief prosecutor of the special court for Sierra Leone, which will be trying Charles Taylor, former president of Liberia and war lord there.
Thanks so much for joining us, Mr. de Silva.
Thank you very much, indeed.
In California, Clarence Ray Allen is scheduled to die by lethal injection in January.
He's been convicted of masterminding the murders of three people.
His lawyers are appealing for clemency.
They say that, at age 75, Clarence Ray Allen is too old and too sick to be executed, and they say he's not alone, as old age is creeping into death row.
NPR's Richard Gonzales reports.
In 1980, Clarence Ray Allen was already serving a life sentence in Folsom State Prison.
He had arranged the murder of his son's girlfriend because she was a witness to another crime Allen had committed.
According to Deputy Attorney General Ward Campbell, Allen had plans for the other witnesses, too.

He conspired to murder the witnesses who testified against him in his first murder trial, and befriended a hit man who was released from Folsom who went out and proceeded to start implementing that conspiracy.
As a result, a former witness named Brian Schletewitz and two innocent bystanders were murdered in Fresno, California, on September 5th, 1980.
For those murders, Allen got the death penalty.
Today, 25 years later, he's blind, diabetic, uses a wheelchair and recently suffered a heart attack.
One geriatric specialist described his heart as a `ticking time bomb.
Annette Carnegie is one of his attorneys.
The thought that such a person would be literally wheeled into a death chamber, strapped to a gurney and then given drugs to stop their heart, etc., is somehow ghoulish.
Yet it is also an image that may become more common.
Nationwide, there are more than 100 seniors on death row.
The majority are here in California, where there are 39 elderly condemned inmates.
Part of this is due to California's time-consuming death penalty appeals process, which can stretch out over two decades.
But for the whole nation, there's another factor at play here, says Jonathan Turley of the George Washington University Law School.
